questions.text: A 67-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of a 1-hour history of severe groin pain, nausea, and vomiting. She has had a groin swelling that worsens with standing, coughing, and straining for the past 3 months. Her pulse is 120/min. Examination shows pallor; there is swelling, erythema, and tenderness to palpation of the right groin that is centered below the inguinal ligament. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is entrapment of an organ between which of the following structures?

choices.text: Inferior epigastric artery and rectus sheath
Transversalis fascia and internal oblique aponeurosis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The linea alba is a longitudinal band in the anterior abdomen extending from the xiphoid process to the pubic symphysis. The conjoint tendon lies in the inferior quadrant of the abdomen, attached medially to the pubic tubercle. Ventral hernias (e.g., epigastric hernias) occur when intra-abdominal contents herniate through the linea alba. This patient, however, presents with pain and swelling below the inguinal ligament.
Image Description:

Transverse section of the abdominal wall above (a) and below (b) the arcuate line

The fibrous rectus sheath is formed of the aponeuroses of the lateral abdominal muscles. It encloses the rectus abdominal muscle. The exact composition of the anterior and posterior part of the rectus sheath depends on the relation to the arcuate line (above or below, a or b). The aponeuroses of the lateral abdominal muscles fuse in the middle of the abdominal wall to form a fibrous line termed linea alba.

B) INCORRECT:

The inferior epigastric artery and the lateral edge of the rectus sheath form the lateral and medial borders of the Hesselbach triangle. Contents of a direct inguinal hernia pass between these two structures. A direct inguinal hernia would appear as a mass above the inguinal ligament, unlike the mass below the inguinal ligament seen here. Moreover, direct inguinal hernias are less prone to strangulation or incarceration when compared to other hernias because the neck of a direct hernia is wide.
Image Description:

Illustration depicting the inguinal area, medial to the inferior epigastric blood vessels (sagittal plane; male patient)

1: internal oblique; 2: transversus abdominis; 3: external oblique aponeurosis; 4: transversalis fascia; 5: parietal peritoneum; 6: intestine; 7: inguinal ligament; 8: lacunar ligament; 9: superior pubic ramus; 10: spermatic cord

C) INCORRECT:

The inguinal canal is bounded superiorly by the conjoint tendon and inferiorly by the inguinal ligament. In the case of an indirect inguinal hernia, intra-abdominal contents pass through the deep inguinal ring and lie within the inguinal canal. However, an indirect inguinal hernia would appear as a mass above the inguinal ligament, unlike the mass below the inguinal ligament seen here. Moreover, indirect inguinal hernias occur typically among men; they are uncommon among women.

D) INCORRECT:

The supravesical fossae lie between the median umbilical ligament and medial umbilical ligaments on either side. Rarely, bowel may herniate into the supravesical fossae (internal hernia), in which case, examination would show tenderness in the suprapubic region, usually without a palpable mass. This patient, however, presents with a tender mass below the inguinal ligament.

E) INCORRECT:

The transversalis fascia and internal oblique aponeurosis contribute to the formation of the rectus sheath, the fascial covering of the spermatic cord, and the conjoint tendon, which forms the medial part of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal. Weakness of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal results in a direct inguinal hernia, which would appear as a mass above the inguinal ligament, unlike the mass below the inguinal ligament seen here. Moreover, direct inguinal hernias are less prone to strangulation or incarceration when compared to other hernias because the neck of a direct hernia is wide.
Image Description:

Transverse section of the abdominal wall above (a) and below (b) the arcuate line

The fibrous rectus sheath is formed of the aponeuroses of the lateral abdominal muscles. It encloses the rectus abdominal muscle. The exact composition of the anterior and posterior part of the rectus sheath depends on the relation to the arcuate line (above or below, a or b). The aponeuroses of the lateral abdominal muscles fuse in the middle of the abdominal wall to form a fibrous line termed linea alba.

F) CORRECT:

In the case of a femoral hernia, intra-abdominal contents (e.g., bowel, mesentery) pass into the femoral canal, which is bounded medially by the lacunar ligament and laterally by the femoral vein. Femoral hernias are more common in women and are likely to strangulate because the femoral canal is narrow.
Image Description:

Topographic anatomy of the femoral canal region and surrounding regions. The femoral ring (yellow outline) forms the base of the femoral canal and is bounded by the inguinal ligament (anteriorly), lacunar ligament (medially), pectineal ligament (posteriorly), and fibrous septum of the femoral vein (laterally). The canal is wider in women. The cribriform fascia is not depicted in order to better visualize the saphenous opening.
questions.hint: A groin swelling that worsens with standing, coughing, and straining is suggestive of a hernia. In a patient with a hernia, severe pain and features of bowel obstruction (e.g., nausea, vomiting) indicate strangulation. As the swelling is located below the midpoint of the inguinal canal, a femoral hernia is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a swelling in the groin for the past 4 weeks. The swelling causes discomfort, but no pain. She was treated for pneumonia 6 weeks ago. She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and inhaled tiotropium. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. Femoral pulses are 2+. There is a nonpulsatile, soft, and nontender groin mass on the left side. The mass arises below the inguinal ligament and increases in size when the patient is asked to cough. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes
Accumulation of pus within the iliopsoas muscle
Incomplete obliteration of the processus vaginalis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes (i.e., inguinal lymphadenopathy), which can manifest as a palpable, nonpulsatile groin mass, is commonly caused by an infection or malignancy in the lower extremities or the perineal region. This patient has no evidence of malignancy or a focus of infection in these regions. Moreover, the mass enlarges with coughing, which is not an expected finding in a mass due to enlarged lymph nodes.

B) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of pus within the iliopsoas muscle (i.e., psoas abscess) can manifest with a palpable groin mass. Diabetes mellitus, which this patient has, is a risk factor for developing a psoas abscess. However, this patient does not have the typical features of a psoas abscess, such as fever, lower back or abdominal pain, antalgic gait, flexion of the hip, or restricted hip movement. Although a psoas abscess can extend into the thigh (i.e., below the inguinal ligament), it arises above the inguinal ligament, unlike the mass seen in this patient that arises below the inguinal ligament.

C) INCORRECT:

Weakness of the transversalis fascia can lead to the development of a direct inguinal hernia. This weakening is commonly secondary to conditions that increase intraabdominal pressure (e.g., obesity or coughing in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease). However, inguinal hernias arise above the inguinal ligament, not below as seen here.
Image Description:

Normally, the only contents of the inguinal canal are the spermatic cord (or round ligament in females) and the ilioinguinal nerve.

Direct inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. The hernial sac lies posteromedial to and outside the spermatic cord

Indirect inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal, and, in the case of large inguinal hernia, also through the superficial inguinal ring. The hernial sac lies within the spermatic cord and is therefore covered by the same tissue layers as the spermatic cord.

D) INCORRECT:

Dilation of the femoral artery leads to a femoral artery aneurysm, which can manifest with a painless groin swelling below the inguinal ligament. However, arterial aneurysms are pulsatile with a palpable thrill, not nonpulsatile like the mass in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Widening of the femoral ring occurs with increasing age and may result in femoral hernia, which has a higher incidence in women, who have a wider pelvis compared to men and, therefore, a larger vascular lacuna. Typical symptoms include painless groin swelling. They manifest as a palpable mass below the inguinal ligament, medial to the femoral vein; an expansive cough impulse is a common finding. In addition to obesity, chronic cough resulting from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease increases intraabdominal pressure, consequently increasing the risk of developing a femoral hernia.
Image Description:

Femoral hernia passes through the vascular lacuna (internal hernial orifice), below the inguinal ligament and usually medial to the femoral vein and runs through the femoral canal until it reaches the saphenous opening (external hernial orifice; approx. 2cm caudal).

The saphenous opening typically contains loose connective and fatty tissue as well as inguinal lymph nodes.

Due to the increased width of the female pelvis, and therefore larger vascular lacuna, femoral hernia occurs predominantly in women.

F) INCORRECT:

Incomplete obliteration of the processus vaginalis during fetal development is the most common cause of indirect inguinal hernia. Although indirect inguinal hernias can extend below the inguinal ligament into the genital region, inguinal hernias arise above the inguinal ligament, not below as seen here.
Image Description:

Left illustration: anatomy of the inguinal canal and spermatic cord
The inguinal canal extends from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial ring.
– Anterior wall: aponeurosis of the external abdominal oblique muscle
– Posterior wall: the transversalis fascia
– Roof: the transversalis fascia, transversus abdominis muscles, and the internal oblique muscle
– Floor: inguinal ligament
– Content: in men, the ilioinguinal nerve, genitofemoral nerve, and spermatic cord; in women, the round ligament of the uterus
The spermatic cord contains the vas deferens, three arteries (testicular artery, artery to the ductus deferens, and cremasteric artery), the pampiniform plexus, and the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve.

Right illustration: the three coverings of the spermatic cord
From superficial to deep, the coverings are the external spermatic fascia (orange), cremasteric fascia (blue), and internal spermatic fascia (green).
questions.hint: This condition carries a high risk of complications (e.g., obstruction, strangulation) and requires early elective surgical repair.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with a 2-day history of progressive right-sided groin pain and recurrent episodes of vomiting. She notices a bulge in her right groin region that lies just below the inguinal ligament. She reports severe pain when straining and mild local erythema. Examination shows a tender bulge in the right groin, and attempts at manual reduction are unsuccessful (see lab result and report).


Heart rate
105/min


Temperature
37.9°C




Test
Result
Normal Values


WBC
11 x 10⁹/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 10⁹/L


Abdominal radiographs: Distended bowel loops suggestive of early obstruction; no evidence of free air
Which diagnosis best explains her presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Direct inguinal hernias occur through Hesselbach’s triangle and are more common in older men. They typically present above the inguinal ligament, unlike the hernia in this patient, which is below the ligament. Additionally, direct inguinal hernias have a wider neck, making incarceration less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Obturator hernias, common in elderly, thin women, may cause bowel obstruction but typically do not form a palpable groin bulge. They pass through the pelvic obturator canal and may cause medial thigh pain due to obturator nerve compression, which is not noted here. The groin mass below the inguinal ligament aligns more with a femoral hernia.

C) CORRECT:

A femoral hernia manifests with a groin mass located just below the inguinal ligament, as seen in this patient. This type of hernia occurs when abdominal contents protrude through the femoral canal, which is narrow and predisposes to incarceration. The patient's symptoms of severe pain, vomiting, and early signs of bowel obstruction, evidenced by distended bowel loops on radiographs, support the diagnosis of an obstructed femoral hernia. In elderly women, the wider femoral canal and decreased connective tissue integrity increase the likelihood of this condition, especially when manual reduction is unsuccessful.

Key learning point: Femoral hernias are more common in women and present as a groin swelling below the inguinal ligament, often leading to bowel obstruction due to incarceration or strangulation.

D) INCORRECT:

Indirect inguinal hernias travel through the deep inguinal ring and present above the inguinal ligament, following the path of the spermatic cord or round ligament. They are more common in younger males. The hernia's location below the inguinal ligament and the patient's demographic details suggest a different hernia type.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents with 24 hours of progressive, crampy abdominal pain, nausea, and multiple episodes of vomiting. She has not passed stool or flatus in 12 hours. Examination shows abdominal distension. A small bulge is noted in the right groin below the inguinal ligament. The skin overlying the bulge appears normal, and a cough impulse is absent (see report).


Heart rate
98/min


Blood pressure
110/70 mmHg


Temperature
37°C


Abdominal radiographs: Multiple air-fluid levels in the small bowel; no air in the colon
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient's presentation is indicative of an obstructed femoral hernia. The painful bulge below the inguinal ligament aligns with the typical location of a femoral hernia, which is more common in older women due to a wider femoral canal. Symptoms such as crampy abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and absence of flatus or stool suggest bowel entrapment, leading to mechanical small bowel obstruction. Radiographic findings of multiple air-fluid levels support this diagnosis.

Key learning point: An obstructed hernia manifests with features of bowel obstruction and is characterized by the inability of bowel contents to pass through the herniated segment.

B) INCORRECT:

Sigmoid volvulus typically causes large bowel obstruction, with imaging showing a distended colon and 'coffee-bean' sign. The radiographs here show multiple air-fluid levels in the small bowel with no air in the colon. Moreover, sigmoid volvulus does not cause an externalized mass.

C) INCORRECT:

Indirect inguinal hernias protrude through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal, and the hernial sac passes above the inguinal ligament. These hernias are common in infants and older men. Moreover, the skin overlying a strangulated hernia is typically warm and erythematous.

D) INCORRECT:

Direct inguinal hernias protrude through the Hesselbach triangle and are located above the inguinal ligament, unlike the bulge described below the inguinal ligament in this patient. They are more common in older men, making this diagnosis less likely in an elderly woman.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents with a painful groin bulge for three weeks. The discomfort has progressively worsened, especially when standing. Examination reveals a non-reducible and tender bulge located immediately below the inguinal ligament and lateral to the pubic tubercle.
Which of the following diagnoses best explains this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Direct inguinal hernias protrude through the floor of the inguinal canal and present as a bulge above the inguinal ligament, typically medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. The described hernia is below the inguinal ligament and lateral to the pubic tubercle, which is consistent with a femoral hernia, not a direct inguinal hernia.

B) CORRECT:

Femoral hernias occur when abdominal contents protrude through the femoral canal, located just below the inguinal ligament and lateral to the pubic tubercle. The narrow femoral canal predisposes these hernias to incarceration and strangulation. They are more common in elderly women due to anatomical factors such as a wider femoral canal. The presentation of a tender, non-reducible groin bulge in this specific location supports the diagnosis of a femoral hernia.

Key learning point: Femoral hernias occur below the inguinal ligament and lateral to the pubic tubercle, are more common in women, and have a higher risk of strangulation compared to inguinal hernias.

C) INCORRECT:

Indirect inguinal hernias originate at the deep inguinal ring and travel through the inguinal canal, presenting as a bulge above the inguinal ligament. The hernia described is below the inguinal ligament and lateral to the pubic tubercle, inconsistent with the path of an indirect inguinal hernia.

D) INCORRECT:

Obturator hernias protrude through the obturator canal and rarely produce an externally palpable groin bulge. They often present with small bowel obstruction or Howship-Romberg sign. The described tender, non-reducible bulge below the inguinal ligament aligns with a femoral hernia, not an obturator hernia.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman presents with a slowly enlarging bulge in her upper thigh, just below the inguinal ligament, for the past month. She notices it more when upright, but it is not painful. She denies any bowel habit changes, nausea, or vomiting. Physical examination reveals a small, soft mass over the femoral canal that does not change significantly with supine position.
Which of the following management approaches is most appropriate?

choices.text: Schedule imaging studies prior to surgical consideration
Daily application of a supportive truss
Elective surgical repair of the femoral hernia

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Imaging is unnecessary when the clinical presentation clearly indicates a femoral hernia, as in this case. The patient's demographic and examination findings support the diagnosis, and imaging would delay necessary surgical intervention without providing additional diagnostic value.

B) INCORRECT:

A supportive truss is not recommended for femoral hernias due to the risk of incarceration and strangulation. The truss does not correct the defect and may delay necessary surgical intervention, leaving the patient at risk for complications.

C) CORRECT:

Femoral hernias, particularly in older women, occur due to the protrusion of intra-abdominal contents through the femoral canal. The narrow neck of the femoral canal increases the risk of incarceration and strangulation, even in the absence of symptoms. Elective surgical repair is recommended to prevent these complications. Surgical intervention, whether open or laparoscopic, provides definitive treatment and reduces the risk of acute bowel compromise.

Key learning point: Femoral hernias have a high risk of complications, and surgical repair is recommended even if asymptomatic; both open mesh repair and laparoscopic repair are appropriate management options.

D) INCORRECT:

Watchful waiting is not appropriate for femoral hernias due to their high risk of incarceration and strangulation, even if initially asymptomatic. The femoral canal's narrow space predisposes to trapping bowel or omentum, necessitating surgical intervention to prevent acute complications.
